intro: Sidalcea hickmanii subsp. petraea, commonly known as Hickman's catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its low-growing habit and clusters of pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and is adapted to dry, rocky habitats. It is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes mallows and hibiscus. Its botanical features make it a unique and rare species found primarily in specific desert environments.
